docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court decision to uphold a ban on a type of abortion, has huge political implications but, as a practical matter, is unlikely to have much of an effect.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Supreme Court’s decision to uphold the federal Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act, represents a major departure from how the court has framed the abortion issue for the past 34 years.

headline.main: A Sharp Turn for the Supreme Court on Abortion (9 Letters)
headline.print_headline: A Sharp Turn for the Supreme Court on Abortion

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''In Reversal of Course, Justices, 5-4, Back Ban on Abortion Method'' (front page, April 19):

headline.main: A Sharp Turn for the Supreme Court on Abortion

docs.abstract: Nine letters comment on Supreme Court decision upholding ban on some late-term abortions (Apr 19 article); Joan Malin, president and chief executive of Planned Parenthood, calls decision assault on women's health and rights and says Americans should be outraged; Dr Deborah Oyer, board member of National Abortion Federation, abhors decision because it injects government into doctor-patient relationship; Rabbi Avi Shafran, public affairs director of Agudath Israel of America, says abortion procedure prohibited by decision is, in effect, infanticide; Emily Rubin argues decision puts doctors in precarious position; Lawrence Longua abhors Apr 19 editorial on Supreme Court decision; Jennifer Rolnick says decision is clear assault on women's rights; Bonnie O'Neil applauds decision; Aviva Briefel finds decision troubling because it places higher value on fetus than woman; Dr George Ehrlich is appalled by decision; drawing
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''In Reversal of Course, Justices, 5-4, Back Ban on Abortion Method'' (front page, April 19):

docs.lead_paragraph: The Los Angeles Times editorial on the Supreme Court decision upholding the federal Partial-Birth Abortion Ban Act includes a sentence that suggests Gonzales v. Carhart ultimately doesn't mean very much for either side of the abortion debate: "This muddled decision doesn't attack the basic holding of Roe v. Wade, and it will have no effect on the vast majority of abortions performed in this country."

docs.lead_paragraph: Blogs are in overdrive about the Supreme Court's 5-4 decision today to uphold a nationwide ban on a procedure known by opponents as "partial birth" abortion.

headline.main: BlogTalk: The Supreme Court and Abortion

docs.abstract: The left is debating just how unhappy it should be. The right isn't as happy as you'd think. And the legal blogs are parsing the decisions for hints about the future of abortion jurisprudence.
docs.snippet: The left is debating just how unhappy it should be. The right isn't as happy as you'd think. And the legal blogs are parsing the decisions for hints about the future of abortion jurisprudence.

docs.abstract: Dear Mom, I've been ruminating on something. We've spoken before about the work/family debate and I've told you how heated these conversations with women my own age can get. Women who plan to be full-time mothers or to stop work entirely for a few years to raise their children are usually on the offensive at [...]
